But you know, as many times as I've read the Bible, and I've read it quite a few times, I've never found the Bible to tell me that. That if I follow God I'll have no problems, I'll have no difficulties, I'll have no opposition. In fact, I read over and over, throughout the pages of this book, people that follow the Lord, that because they follow the Lord, face difficulties. But God knew about them, and God sustained them, and God blessed them, and God grew them. You know, some of the most fascinating accounts in the Word of God, if we were to ask the children this evening, I don't like using the word story when we talk about a biblical account, but many people refer to it as a Bible story. I like using the word biblical account because its story kind of gives the idea that it's a story. Something that maybe is just made up. They're biblical accounts. And I know it's just a little nuance of syntax, but that's just my personal approach to it. But if we were to ask the kids this evening, or maybe even some of the adults, what biblical account is your favorite? I'm sure some would speak about David and Goliath. Joseph in the pit, being delivered, in the prison, being delivered. Maybe Daniel, right? Maybe Daniel the Den of Lies, maybe Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego. We could go on and on. But you know what's amazing about most of those accounts? We read of those and we find that they face some difficulties, they face some adversity and some opposition, and God showed Himself mighty. He revealed His power and we look at Him and say, man, look at what God did. And then we face a difficulty and say, oh, woe is me. What might God do in our lives? How might God show Himself real in your life, in my life? Jacob's a man just like we are. He dealt with fear just like we do. He took it to the Lord and just like we do, we sometimes try to keep our hand in it. I'm thankful and we'll look at it in its entirety next week that God met with him at the end of chapter 32. You read chapter 33, it's a great reunion that takes place between Jacob and Esau. It's amazing to see the reconciliation between those two men. It's a blessing. But I hope that as we look at these, just 23 verses tonight, this preparation of Jacob, that as we relate to Jacob, say, Lord, would You help us? Would You help me to be able to see in the life of Jacob what sometimes I even do in my own life? And help me to keep my hands out of it. Let God have His way. Let God do what only God can do because He is able. We sing it. He is able. He is able. I know He is able. He is able to deliver thee. We sing the hymn. Deliver thee from what? From anything. From anything. Isn't that what Darius said to Daniel? He said, Daniel, is thy God that thou servest continually, able to deliver thee? Isn't it amazing that Darius had such a high view of Daniel and of Daniel's God? Because Daniel was a man that walked with God. Daniel had a great testimony. And Daniel returned word, he is. They've not touched me all night. Those men that accused, they didn't hit the ground before they were devoured. Our God is able. Let's pray. Father, we love You. We thank You for loving us. As we look at this account tonight of Jacob and his preparation, Lord, I pray that in our lives, we deal with opposition, whether real or assumed. As we see in the text tonight, this was just an assumed problem, the perception of Jacob. Worst case scenario thinking. No doubt in our lives, there are times that we've been guilty of the same thing. I thank You that Jacob prayed. Lord, I pray that we'd come to You, seeking Your face. Lord, I pray that we'd learn from the life of Jacob to leave it with You, to trust You, to know that You are the God that spoke everything into existence, that You rule and that You reign, that You're our God and that You're able. So often, we mess things up by trying to get our own hands into the mix. Lord, I pray that You would help us to simply trust You, help us to follow You, help us to obey You. I pray that in a moment of invitation this evening, that You'd move and work in hearts and lives as only You can. Well, thank You for all that You'll do, for it's in Christ's name we pray.
